'''Love''' is a constellation of [[emotion]]s and [[experience]]s related to a sense of strong [[affection]] or profound [[oneness (concept)|oneness]].<ref name="oxford"/> The meaning of ''love'' varies relative to context. [[Romantic love]] is seen as an [[ineffability|ineffable]] [[feeling]] of intense attraction shared in [[passion]]ate or intimate [[interpersonal attraction|attraction]] and [[intimacy|intimate]] [[interpersonal relationship|interpersonal]] and [[human sexuality|sexual]] relationships.<ref name="dic">http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/love</ref> Though often linked to personal relations, love is often given a broader [[signification]], a love of [[human race|humanity]], of [[nature]], with [[life]] itself, or a oneness with the [[Universe]], a universal love. Love can also be construed as [[Platonic love]],<ref name="PlatonicSchool">{{cite book |last=Kristeller |first=Paul Oskar |title=Renaissance Thought and the Arts: collected essays |publisher=Princeton University |year=1980 |id=ISBN 0691020108}}</ref> [[love (religious views)|religious love]],<ref name="Gita">{{cite book |last= Mascaró |first=Juan |title=The Bhagavad Gita |publisher=Penguin Classics |year=2003 |id= ISBN 0140449183}}(J. Mascaró translator)</ref> [[familial love]], and, more casually, great affection for anything considered strongly pleasurable, desirable, or preferred, to include activities and foods.<ref name="IdiomNote">Casual application of the word ''love'' also includes [[idiom]]atic expressions and uses with differing connotations. For example, as a sardonic expression of disapproval: "I just love how politicians always make empty promises."</ref><ref name="dic"/> This diverse range of meanings in the singular word ''love'' is often contrasted with the plurality of [[Greek words for love|Greek words for ''love'']], reflecting the concept's depth, versatility, and complexity.
−
"love" is an extremely hard concept to explain. it is the feeling of closeness or loyalty somone feels towards someone else or something. this deep spiritual emotion is the most powerful weapon mankind has. everyday, everyone has someone or something they love. usually, it is used when talking of love of family or a partner such as a girlfriend or wife. for example, to say "i love you cloe" is expressing the understanding of the strong feeling of affection one has for another, in this case "cloe". the explanation of love is so deep and mysterious, it is a feeling all human beings are born with, like conscience. the phrase "i love you" is used so much in man's history to symbolise the unity between people.
  −   −
'''Love''' is a feeling of embarrasment and sexual experience related to a sense of strong loyalty or profound [[oneness (concept)|oneness]].<ref name="oxford"/> The meaning of ''love'' varies relative to context. [[Romantic love]] is seen as an [[ineffability|ineffable]] [[feeling]] of intense attraction shared in [[passion]]ate or intimate [[interpersonal attraction|attraction]] and [[intimacy|intimate]] [[interpersonal relationship|interpersonal]] and [[human sexuality|sexual]] relationships.<ref name="dic">http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/love</ref> Though often linked to personal relations, love is often given a broader [[signification]], a love of [[human race|humanity]], of [[nature]], with [[life]] itself, or a oneness with the [[Universe]], a universal love. Love can also be construed as [[sexual love]],<ref name="PlatonicSchool">{{cite book |last=Kristeller |first=Paul Oskar |title=Renaissance Thought and the Arts: collected essays |publisher=Princeton University |year=1980 |id=ISBN 0691020108}}</ref> [[love (religious views)|religious love]],<ref name="Gita">{{cite book |last= Mascaró |first=Juan |title=The Bhagavad Gita |publisher=Penguin Classics |year=2003 |id= ISBN 0140449183}}(J. Mascaró translator)</ref> [[familial love]], and, more casually, great affection for anything considered strongly pleasurable, desirable, or preferred, to include activities and foods.<ref name="IdiomNote">Casual application of the word ''love'' also includes [[idiom]]atic expressions and uses with differing connotations. For example, as a sardonic expression of disapproval: "I just love how politicians always make empty promises."</ref><ref name="dic"/> This diverse range of meanings in the singular word ''love'' is often contrasted with the plurality of [[Greek words for love|Greek words for ''love'']], reflecting the concept's depth, versatility, and complexity.
